@graph.rdfs:label: Towards Coding Social Science Datasets with Language Models (Rytting et al.)

@graph.schema:name: Pigeonholing Partisans (PP) – 7,675 open-ended descriptions of Democrats/Republicans (Rothschild et al. 2019 + synthetic)
CAP-coded U.S. Congressional hearing summaries (1946–2010)
@graph.schema:size: >10,000 summaries (subset n=326 used for intercoder comparison)

@graph.schema:name: New York Times Front Page headlines 1996–2006 (Boydstun 2013)
@graph.schema:description: 28 CAP media categories; random subsample n=560 used for intercoder study

@graph.schema:name: The Guardian Populism survey responses (2018)
@graph.schema:size: >20,000 responses; 4,000 coded by highly-trained humans; random subset n=1,300 used for GPT-3 comparison

@graph.rdfs:label: Human coding of texts across four datasets (lightly-trained for PP/NYT/Congress, intensively-trained for Guardian Populism)
Design of few-shot prompts (2–4 exemplars) for each coding task
Zero/few-shot coding of all four datasets using GPT-3 (text-davinci-002/003 era)

rdip:outputDataset.schema:name: GPT-3 codes for 7,675 PP descriptions (5 dimensions)
GPT-3 CAP codes for congressional hearing summaries
GPT-3 CAP codes for 560 NYT headlines
GPT-3 binary populism codes for 1,300 Guardian responses

@graph.rdfs:label: Post-hoc calibration of GPT-3 token probabilities using balanced validation set (Zhao et al. 2021-style bias normalization)
Training and application of bag-of-words Support Vector Classifier (SVC) baseline on Guardian Populism data
Computation of intercoder reliability metrics (ICC1k, ICC3k, Fleiss’ kappa, joint probability of agreement) and accuracy comparisons

rdip:usedSoftware.schema:name: R / Python (irr, psych, or sklearn.metrics packages implied)

rdip:outputDataset.schema:name: Tables and figures of agreement statistics across all four applications
